Functionalized IRMOF-3 as efficient heterogeneous catalyst for the synthesis of cyclic carbonates Xi Zhou a b Yi Zhang b Xiangui Yang b Liangzhong Zhao a Gongying Wang b ⁎ a Department of Biological and Chemical Engineering, Shaoyang University, Shaoyang 422000 Hunan, PR China b Chengdu Institute of Organic Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Chengdu 610041 Sichuan, PR China ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +86 28 85215405; fax: +86 28 85220713. Graphical abstract Functionalized IRMOF-3 was developed as a novel heterogeneous catalyst for the solventless synthesis of cyclic carbonates without any co-catalyst. It performs excellent catalytic activity and selectivity. After simple separation, it can be reused without viewable loss of activity. And the framework can be retained after the coupling reaction. Highlights ► Functionalized IRMOF-3 was developed as a novel heterogeneous catalyst for the synthesis of cyclic carbonates. ► F-IRMOF-3 performed excellent activity and reusability without any co-catalyst. ► The framework of functionalized IRMOF-3 contains acid (Zn2+) and basic (I−) bi-active centers. ► There are synergetic catalytic effect between acid and basic centers. Functionalized isoreticular metal–organic framework-3 (IRMOF-3) was developed as a novel heterogeneous catalyst for the solventless synthesis of cyclic carbonates without any co-catalyst. The results showed that functionalized IRMOF-3 performed excellent activity, selectivity and reusability. The effects of reaction temperature, pressure, and time on the yield of propylene carbonate were tested. And the reaction mechanism was also discussed. Keywords Cyclic carbonate Heterogeneous catalyst IRMOF-3 Carbon dioxide 1 Introduction Chemical fixation of carbon dioxide (CO2) has attracted much attention because CO2 is an abundant, inexpensive and nontoxic C1 feed stock [1]. Coupling of CO2 and epoxide to synthesis cyclic carbonates is one of the most promising methodologies in this area [2–4]. Cyclic carbonates can be used as excellent aprotic polar solvents, precursors for producing polycarbonates, fine chemicals, etc. [2]. Many catalysts have been developed for the coupling reaction, such as alkali metal halides, quaternary ammonium salts, ionic liquids, transition metal complexes, metal oxides, zeolites, functional polymers, and supported catalysts [2–25]. However, most of them suffer from low catalytic activity, harsh reaction condition, poor reusability and requiring of co-solvent. As discussed above, it is still very important to develop highly efficient heterogeneous catalysts for the solventless synthesis of cyclic carbonates. Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), also known as porous coordination polymers, consist of metallic nodes bonded by organic linkers. MOFs perform some special properties, such as ultrahigh porosity, high surface area, and easily functionalized [26–28]. In the past decades, they have been widely used in gas storage and separation [29], magnetism [30], catalysis [31–33]. Recently, it is reported that MIXMOF/Et4NBr and MOF-5/n-Bu4NBr are efficient catalyst systems for the synthesis of cyclic carbonates [34,35]. However, the existence of quaternary ammonium salts results the separation of catalyst from products being difficult. In this paper, functionalized IRMOF-3 [Zn4O(ABDC)3, ABDC=2-amino-1,4-benzene dicarboxylate] was developed as heterogeneous catalyst for the solventless synthesis of cyclic carbonates without any co-catalyst. Functionalized IRMOF-3 performed excellent catalytic activity and reusability. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation and characterization of F-IRMOF-3 IRMOF-3 was prepared according to the literature reported by Huang et al. [36]: 6.4g (64mmol) of triethylamine was slowly added to a N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) solution (160mL) containing 4.8g (16mmol) of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O and 1.32g (8mmol) of 2-aminoterephthalic acid under stirring at room temperature for 1.5h. The solid was filtered and thoroughly washed with CH2Cl2. A sample of IRMOF-3 (2.4g) was activated by guest exchange with CH2Cl2 (80mL) for 20h. The sample was then filtered and dried in vacuum at 130°C. Then, the activated sample was suspended in dry DMF (80mL) and treated with three equivalent of methyl iodide (CH3I) at room temperature for 4 days. The resulting powder was collected by filtration, then thoroughly washed with CH2Cl2 and dried under vacuum at 130°C. The X-ray diffraction patterns were collected on X-ray diffractometer (XPERT PRO) using a Cu Kα radiation source (λ =1.54056Å), operating at 40kV and 45mA. A continuous mode was used for collecting data at a scanning speed of 0.03°/S. FT-IR spectra were obtained by Nicolet 560 in KBr pellets. The surface area was detected by Builder SSA-4200 and calculated with BET equation. In order to test the iodine content of catalyst, functionalized IRMOF-3 was digested using dilute acid and analyzed by ICP-AES (IRIS-1000). 2.2 Typical procedure for the coupling reaction All reagents were used without treatment. All coupling reactions were carried out in 250mL stainless steel autoclaves equipped with a magnetic stirrer. In a typical reaction, the reactor was charged with desired amount of catalyst and propylene oxide. After sealing, CO2 was introduced into the reactor until desired pressure was reached. The reactor was then heated to a desired temperature with stirring. After the required time of reaction, the reactor was cooled to room temperature, and the unreacted CO2 was released very slowly. The product mixture was analyzed by GC (Shanghai Analytical Co. GC-112A) equipped with a Supelco WAX™-10 column (30m×0.32mm×0.5μm). The structure of product was defined by GC–MS (HP 6890/5973). In the experiments to test the reusability of catalyst, functionalized IRMOF-3 was separated by centrifugation, washed using diethyl ether. After drying in vacuum, functionalized IRMOF-3 was reused for the next time. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization The samples are designated with the reaction time of functionalization. For example, F-IRMOF-3-2d represents the sample produced by the reaction of IRMOF-3 with CH3I for 2 days (Scheme 1 ). FT-IR spectrums of IRMOF-3 and functionalized IRMOF-3 (F-IRMOF-3) are shown in Fig. 1 . In comparison with IRMOF-3, there are new peaks at 3010cm−1, 1483cm−1 and 944cm−1 for F-IRMOF-3 (Fig. 1). It means that CH3I has been introduced into the framework of IRMOF-3 resulting in the conversion of partial NH2 to the group of quaternary ammonium salt (Scheme 1). The height of these new peaks increases with prolonging the reaction time of functionalization, indicating that the conversion of IRMOF-3 increase (Fig. 1). According to the iodine content in the framework of functionalized IRMOF-3, about 40%, 60%, 65% of NH2 convert to the group of quaternary ammonium salt for F-IRMOF-3-2d, F-IRMOF-3-4d, F-IRMOF-3-6d, respectively (Table 1 ). All catalysts are examined by power X-ray diffraction (PXRD), and the results show that the structure of IRMOF-3 is well retained even after functionalization with CH3I for 6 days (Fig. 2 ). In addition, the surface area of F-IRMOF-3 is lower than that of IRMOF-3, and decreases with increasing the functionalization rate (Table 1). 3.2 Coupling reaction with various catalysts The catalytic performance of various catalysts for the coupling reaction of CO2 with propylene oxide (PO) was investigated, and the results were summarized in Table 2 . IRMOF-3 had almost no catalytic activity without co-catalyst under desired conditions. When CH3I was used alone as catalyst, the activity was also found to be poor (Entry 2, Table 2). If equivalent molar of CH3I and IRMOF-3 were added into the coupling reaction system, the yield of propylene carbonate (PC) quickly increased to 40% (Entry 3, Table 2). It means that there is a synergetic catalytic effect between IRMOF-3 and CH3I. However, F-IRMOF-3-2d performed much higher activity than IRMOF-3/CH3I (Entry 4, Table 2). The reason may be that quaternary ammonium salt group of F-IRMOF-3-2d performed higher activity than CH3I for opening the ring of PO, and CH3I were hardly grafted on IRMOF-3 under desired reaction conditions to synthesis F-IRMOF-3. If the amount of F-IRMOF-3-2d increased from 0.21g to 0.42g, 95% PC yield was obtained with shortening the reaction time from 5h to 2.5h (Entry 5, Table 2). Under the same reaction conditions, the effect of functionalization time of F-IRMOF-3 on the catalytic activity was also studied (Entries 6–8, Table 2). As shown in Table 2, the activity of F-IRMOF-3 was significantly improved with increasing the functionalization time from 2 d to 4 d, and then kept almost constant. By comprehensive consideration, F-IRMOF-3-4d was the best catalyst for the coupling reaction and exhibited a high turn over frequencies (TOF) value (778mmolg−1 h−1). It performed even higher catalytic activity than the homogeneous catalyst system MIXMOF/Et4NBr (Entries 8 and 9) [34]. In additional, F-IRMOF-3-4d showed higher catalytic activity than most of other heterogeneous catalyst reported by previous literatures, such as MgO (0.9mmolg−1 h−1) [13], SmOCl (4.1mmolg−1 h−1) [15], CLPN (127mmolg−1 h−1) [20], PDVB-HEIMBr (70mmolg−1 h−1) [21], PS-Thr (16mmolg−1 h−1) [25]. 3.3 Effect of reaction conditions on the PC yield Effect of the reaction temperature on the PC yield was investigated under 2.0MPa in 1.5h with F-IRMOF-3-4d as catalyst, and the result was shown in Fig. 3 . As expected, the temperature had a remarkable effect on the coupling reaction when the temperature varied from 110°C to 140°C. The yield of PC was quickly increased from 1% to 90% with increasing temperature from 110°C to 130°C, and then slowly increased to 98% when the initial temperature was reached at 140°C. For the continuous rise of temperature gave no viewable change on the PC yield. As shown in Fig. 4 , the pressure also has great effect on the PC yield. The PC yield was quickly increased from 62% to 98% with changing the initial pressure from 1MPa to 2MPa, and then kept almost constant with initial pressure further increasing to 5.0MPa. There were gas–liquid two phases in the coupling reaction system, and the coupling reaction mainly happened in the liquid phase. The higher pressure can improve the concentration of CO2 in liquid and the communication between the gas–liquid two phases. This may be the reason that the PC yield increased with increasing CO2 pressure at low pressure. Above results indicated that the optimum CO2 pressure was 2MPa. In addition, the effect of reaction time on the PC yield was also studied. The result showed that PC yield was only decreased from 98% to 92% with shortening reaction time from 1.5h to 1h (Fig. 5 ). It means that the coupling reaction mainly occurred in the first hour under desired reaction conditions. 3.4 Reusability of F-IRMOF-3 The reusability of F-IRMOF-3-4d was also examined. After the completion of the reaction, the catalyst was filtered, washed with diethyl ether, dried under vacuum, and reused for the next time. As shown in Fig. 6 , F-IRMOF-3-4d could be reused for the coupling reaction in 4 runs without viewable change of its catalytic activity. Fig. 7 showed that the XRD pattern of the recovered catalyst matched well that of the fresh one. No significant differences were observed, indicating that the framework of F-IRMOF-3-4d was well retained. Above results demonstrated that F-IRMOF-3-4d performed good reusability. It must be pointed out that F-IRMOF-3-4d could not expose to air for a long time. Otherwise, the crystal structure of F-IRMOF-3-4d would decompose by the influence of atmospheric water [37]. 3.5 Coupling reactions of CO2 with other epoxides To demonstrate the catalytic activity of F-IRMOF-3-4d, the coupling reactions of CO2 with other representative epoxides were also conducted for the synthesis of corresponding cyclic carbonates. As shown in Table 3 , the catalyst was also applicable to listed terminal epoxides with high yield of corresponding cyclic carbonates. Although styrene oxide was a low active substrate due to the steric hindrance, the yield of corresponding cyclic carbonate could reach at 84% by prolonging the reaction time to 5h. 3.6 Reaction mechanism Song et al. demonstrated that the synergistic effect of between Zn4O cluster (activate the epoxy ring) in MOF-5 and Br− (open the epoxy ring) from n-Bu4NBr is the main reason for the high catalytic activity of the catalyst system [35]. Herein, F-IRMOF-3 has Zn4O and I− active sites, and they can play the role of activating and opening the epoxy ring, respectively. In addition, F-IRMOF-3 also has the group of NH2 which can activate the epoxy ring through the hydrogen bond [38,39]. Based on above reasons, a plausible reaction mechanism was proposed for the coupling reaction catalyzed by F-IRMOF-3. The coordination of the oxygen atom of the epoxide with Zn4O or the hydrogen of NH2 in F-IRMOF-3 leads to the polarization of CO, while I− attacks the less sterically hindered carbon atom to open the epoxide ring. Then, the oxygen anion interacts with CO2 forming an alkylcarbonate anion, which is converted to the corresponding cyclic carbonate. Simultaneously, the catalyst is generated. 4 Conclusion F-IRMOR-3 has been developed as a highly efficient heterogeneous catalyst for the solventless synthesis of cyclic carbonates without any co-catalyst. It performed excellent activity under mild conditions. After simple separation, the catalyst could be reused at least 4 times without viewable loss of activity. The tunability of functionalized metal organic framework catalyst could be a potential criterion to make it more viable towards its possible industrial applications for the synthesis of cyclic carbonates. coredata.dc:description: Functionalized isoreticular metal–organic framework-3 (IRMOF-3) was developed as a novel heterogeneous catalyst for the solventless synthesis of cyclic carbonates without any co-catalyst. The results showed that functionalized IRMOF-3 performed excellent activity, selectivity and reusability. The effects of reaction temperature, pressure, and time on the yield of propylene carbonate were tested. And the reaction mechanism was also discussed.
coredata.dc:title: Functionalized IRMOF-3 as efficient heterogeneous catalyst for the synthesis of cyclic carbonates
coredata.prism:publicationName: Journal of Molecular Catalysis A: Chemical
